hints_html: Use a fundamental theorem that connects integration and differentiation.

Use a \emph{fundamental} theorem that connects integration and

hints_raw: Use a ''fundamental'' theorem that connects integration and differentiation.
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
By the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, if

\[\begin{aligned} F(x) = \int_0^x \ln(2 + \sin t) dt\end{aligned}\]

then

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle F'(x) = \ln(2 + \sin x).\end{aligned}\]

Similarly,

\[\begin{aligned} G(y) = \int_y^0 \ln(2 + \sin t) dt = - \int_0^y \ln(2 + \sin t) dt\end{aligned}\]

so the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus tells us that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle G'(y) = - \ln(2 + \sin y).\end{aligned}\]

We now can evaluate

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle F'(\pi/2) = \ln(2 + \sin(\pi/2)) = \ln (2+1) = \ln 3\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle G'(\pi/2) = - \ln(2+\sin(\pi/2)) = -\ln (2+1) = - \ln 3.\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
If

\[\begin{aligned} F(x) = \int_0^x \ln(2+\sin t)\,dt\end{aligned}\]

and

\[\begin{aligned} G(y) = \int_y^0 \ln(2+\sin t)\,dt,\end{aligned}\]

find \(\displaystyle F'\left(\frac{\pi}2\right)\) and \(\displaystyle G'\left(\frac{\pi}2\right)\).
